document.title: National Standards for Personal Financial Education

jurisdiction.title: Jump$tart Coalition for Personal Financial Literacy

FEA4AD2688F14C0994F51F8A4CFC647A.description: Explain how extended warranties or service contracts are similar to and different from insurance.

03849DCDAA79416CBDA8D74065653236.description: Evaluate the costs and benefits of buying an extended warranty on a specific item (e.g. cellphone, laptop, or vehicle) considering the likelihood of product failure, cost of replacing the item, and price of the warranty.

CA94506C86EA4B10AB8FAD94D77772EE.description: Extended warranties and service contracts are like an insurance policy.

1491B8DD874A4A698590A959DC26CB89.description: Explain the steps an identity theft victim should take to limit losses and restore personal security.

8D989BA0FD2A4A53A5BD44CFF3423DB7.description: Recommend strategies to reduce the risk of identity theft and financial fraud.

1E837657E2284F769658A4A55E9D3BDA.description: Describe conditions under which individuals should and should not disclose their Social Security numbers, account numbers, or other sensitive information.

34C10FACAFE6464A8AE8A3E053AD648C.description: Provide examples of how online behavior, e-mail and text-message scams, telemarketers, and other methods make consumers vulnerable to privacy infringement, identity theft, and fraud.

277F15E294434CC6ACECBA9F020BE77A.description: Online transactions and failure to safeguard personal documents can make consumers vulnerable to privacy infringement, identity theft, and fraud.

AA17AEF3260F4459B1CA5D84AFFC0042.description: Investigate the legal consequence for individuals who are convicted of insurance fraud.

D3C944A7EF9748DB892F85A821CF40BB.description: Insurance fraud is a crime that encompasses illegal actions by the buyer (e.g., falsified claims) or seller (e.g., representing non-existent companies) of an insurance contract.

EB6DF74A2C44432184497842CAE62881.description: Compare the Medicare and Medicaid programs based on who they cover and how they are funded.

FEDC0311F62146548DE69DB8B9CA9547.description: Discuss how state unemployment programs can help reduce economic hardship caused by job losses during a recession or pandemic.

B2C533C70443489C822AF817D52E3F2B.description: Unemployment insurance, Medicaid, and Medicare are public insurance programs that protect individuals from economic hardship caused by certain risks.

17000F100201463E99606A1C488BC7D3.description: Discuss the benefits and costs of purchasing life insurance on the primary earners in a household.

AE31C07895244792B481C748582DC113.description: Explain how a person’s death can result in financial losses to others.

73A44A26ADDA47BD8A2C15605714EA24.description: Life insurance provides funds for beneficiaries in the event of an insured person’s death. Policy proceeds are intended to replace the insured’s lost wages and/or to fund their dependents’ future financial needs.

CB6887BACD8C458F83F5DE23EAA62CB5.description: Identify factors that influence the cost of renter’s insurance and homeowners’ insurance.

24705102A7A748B49BF59E11D6CD081E.description: Describe situations where someone may be liable for injuries or damages to another person or their property.

2B2A5AF6AA184961B24474EC7336512D.description: Explain the primary types of losses covered by auto, homeowner’s, and renter’s insurance policies.

4DC09FC9F90046788D151D394705AE97.description: Auto, homeowner’s and renter’s insurance reimburse policyholders for financial losses to their covered property and the costs of legal liability for their damages to other people or property.

6E8CBF2FCFA4431096226E07D6C610E3.description: Assess the extent of financial risk and need for disability insurance using hypothetical disability scenarios.

7861E8FE3C9B4F529E0E482952DEDA45.description: Compare disability coverage offered by individual policies, employee benefit plans, Social Security, workers’ compensation, and temporary disability programs (in some states).

86C3E058AE6344079F9EAD70C9C00737.description: Disability insurance replaces income lost when a person is unable to earn their regular income due to injury or illness. In addition to privately purchased policies, some government programs provide disability protection.

20C313400B864491AED0C920FA7A68CF.description: Estimate the effect on different health insurance deductibles and coinsurance rates on out-of-pocket medical costs.

D88F32BEE2BE405BB435A742D4267634.description: Compare the cost of health insurance to the potential financial consequences of not having health insurance.

0ED1FE151DDA4670A6A7EEC028EC9911.description: Discuss the advantages of obtaining health insurance coverage through an employer plan versus buying private insurance or being uninsured.

15FEF5882DF24335AC66AA7813D7A2F3.description: Health insurance provides coverage for medically necessary health care and may also cover some preventive care. It is sometimes offered as an employee benefit with the employer paying some or all of the premium cost.

9465BC9574504214A74F25C7EB131DE4.description: Discuss the pros and cons of buying an auto insurance policy with a higher deductible.

841A45D5DDAB41459E688E2F4E52D022.description: Explain why taking a safe driving course can lower a driver’s auto insurance premium.

0AC82F39344D46D4A981E0EF870A4835.description: Research factors that result in lower auto insurance premiums.

3A9E7AEAA24E47B99B5ECBC38F1A8243.description: Insurance premiums are lower for people who take actions to reduce the likelihood and/or financial cost of losses and for those who buy policies with larger deductibles or copayments.

FFA92A0BBEE44515A3E2F2D6240EF587.description: Research the minimum auto liability insurance required in the state they live in and whether it is sufficient to cover typical auto accident financial losses.

2CDB15509747424280FB05FA3BBC6E93.description: Discuss why most states mandate auto liability coverage.

ADEDD4105CF64FE29D72B9B353B0DB57.description: Explain why homeowners’ insurance is required by a lender when a homeowner takes out a mortgage.

7084EC8E7BF74806AE3C62C86D8A9803.description: Some types of insurance coverage are mandatory.

64BFD51DB9DF45B6B2E244ABEB9B8407.description: Recommend types of insurance needed by people with different characteristics.

F3FA326643A048F9AA55302A39D701CB.description: Identify individual characteristics that influence insurance purchase decisions.

47F8C5FDFF994721800D46BD5E344125.description: The decision to buy insurance depends on perceived risk exposure, the price of insurance coverage, and individual characteristics such as risk attitudes, age, occupation, lifestyle, and financial profile.

BD508BC97CE2462FA2B9E009CA0D91DB.description: Analyze the conditions under which it is appropriate for young adults to have life, health, and disability insurance.

4A2BC809E3A34117AC2D753B4F7775AE.description: Discuss whether a premium paid to insure against a crash that never happens is wasted.

B3EE33D42C024FE593751CC0529B163E.description: People vary with respect to their willingness to accept risk and in how much they are willing to pay for insurance that will allow them to minimze future financial loss.

3B512B152A2644CBA03CFFEAFCF2FB13.description: Explain how using payday loans can cause a cycle of debt.

F013622B62BF4BD582E5C6E2BEDC3392.description: Discuss the costs and benefits of using alternative financial services relative to traditional banking.

DA9C60C2CABC4C908ADFED2AB92CC8A1.description: Identify products and practices that are classified as alternative financial services.

2D5070422AFB4B7DBD5B6EA6FD686782.description: Alternative financial services, such as payday loans, checkcashing services, pawnshops, and instant tax refunds, provide easy access to credit, often at relatively high cost.

097F5B4291734EA3A6787EE8552C531B.description: Research where to find credible sources of up-to-date information on credit rights and responsibilities.

E79CFAA22ECB4D95A2FC5F6EC8A5DB90.description: Discuss the importance of protecting borrowers from discrimination and abusive marketing or collection practices

FAC0E29E25C04139A4670DD594030953.description: Explain the rationale behind laws that require people to have access to full information about credit cards and loans before they borrow money.

054D9308E6BF45B69BF603E390CD5866.description: Consumer credit protection laws govern disclosure of credit terms, discrimination in borrowing, and debt collection practices.

2BDC04E039F14DC59A759BEFECA6DB5D.description: Compare the results of liquidation versus reorganization bankruptcy.

160D78499D6542A68A7289A1C8987392.description: Investigate the effects of bankruptcy on assets, employment, and future access to credit.

ABEA996A92FA4AF883E9E0F786D05F75.description: Describe the purpose of bankruptcy laws.

6D7A82B227CB40EEB6B2B539CE84E0EB.description: In extreme cases, bankruptcy may be an option for people who are unable to repay their debts.

D293A2D29F064FEE87B4C2B775DA11EC.description: Compare the costs and benefits associated with for-profit versus non-profit credit counseling services.

A52E0315F28A4412B72FDE92B2D1DCD7.description: Create a plan for a person who is having difficulty repaying debt.

068FEE3107684804A0A20CBD44B9E6E3.description: Identify sources of assistance with debt management

C68FAAE26B844F11A9E687F4DEAA1133.description: Describe how failing to repay a loan can negatively impact a person’s finances and life.

2251F508C502467BB191E7DD143FD103.description: Borrowers who face negative consequences because they are unable to repay their debts may be able to seek debt management assistance.

FAD561482F0C4796A4782C51597B3EE1.description: Compare the effect of soft versus hard credit inquiries on a person’s credit score.

A0E89E61E7F945E38B10BE0453415C47.description: Provide examples of benefits associated with having a good credit score.

5C67B5BA8DD5488AAB3550761A265454.description: Explain how landlords, potential employers, and insurance companies use credit reports and credit scores in decisionmaking.

2BA568BEF8614A598C3114FF00298074.description: Credit reports and credit scores may be requested and used by entities other than lenders.

EBDE5BFA86364F668998670CB700129D.description: Recommend ways that a person can increase their credit score

DE214ACC49CB4DFBBB3595114BBDBD08.description: Explain how a borrower’s credit score can impact their cost of credit and their ability to get credit

33BBA5D269BA4872A9B3FBE017A5DB88.description: Identify the main factors that are included in credit score calculations.

BD4965C797614812876BCBF500DC067A.description: A credit score is a numeric rating that assesses a person’s credit risk based on information in their credit report.

2656B98DDEE74A3D8A7B4FC57DB0C7C8.description: Outline the process of disputing inaccurate credit report information.

0CD345BAF5054A0FAF4960AAB69712C3.description: Explain how a person can get a free copy of their credit report and why this is advisable.

2BEAA2218EC1468A8D3E261DCA2DE4F6.description: Assess the value to a potential lender of the information contained in a credit report.

B03D2182E35B430CBD3ED86FB7E21120.description: Identify the primary organizations that maintain and provide consumer credit reports.

8794D267BDA047F49AF59BBEE3CA7FE5.description: Lenders assess creditworthiness of potential borrowers by consulting credit reports compiled by credit bureaus.

0FD881FD404B48AC83811D8C01693934.description: Explain how a down payment makes a borrower more attractive to a lender and motivates loan repayment by the borrower.

3FE2DCA4338D45909A49822151BB83AE.description: For a specified loan amount, compare the monthly loan payment with a 10% down payment versus a 20% down payment.

A82CCADD4930481A9A08B29A9012C717.description: Given the price of a home, estimate the amount of down payment required.

E55976109F0F47018690A011C6367631.description: Identify examples of loans that may require down payments.

4B8382D647694FB18E95BFE4E09C531D.description: Down payments reduce the amount needed to borrow.

9EC33E5D88B14AE783E3E7B915BB6F7D.description: Predict the potential consequences of deferred payment of student loans.

E48F718B97E442B4BE35C2CE8F1C64D3.description: Estimate total interest on various student loans based on interest rates and repayment plans.

7C810E01B20249FD9E83D8B8655E3476.description: Describe the process of applying for a student loan.

AF949ED6BB054BAC9F5F2A143EE8050E.description: Compare federal and private student loans based on interest rates, repayment rules, and other characteristics.

D1616E8771C6430CADDE343719A39D09.description: Federal student loans have lower rates and more favorable repayment terms than private student loans, and may be subsidized.

CCD84F9CFAF44904937DDAC35E5357FB.description: Estimate the reduction in total cost of education and potential student loan debt if they complete their first two years of college at a community college before transferring to a four-year institution.

B1B6A2630BBB49D99409F5CA3D61157D.description: Identify scholarships and grants for which they are eligible.

7E75C19C8F53447182E342186AD532C9.description: Explain the role the FAFSA plays in applying for college financial aid.

EFEBB88FDBA04E40A53BEE37A67BC4F0.description: Describe the different sources of funding for post-secondary education.

043839C4A70C4AD8B73DDEDF15D941BD.description: Post-secondary education is often financed by students and families/caregivers through a combination of scholarships, grants, student loans, work-study, and savings.

C510AD5C2AD64D198FCDCC2D8F5CAEA3.description: Compare monthly mortgage payments for loans that differ in repayment period, amount borrowed, and interest rate.

C4E1EBD5A93C4753AA58245FF9908A27.description: Differentiate between adjustable-rate and fixed-rate mortgages.

EE126E6D03934033BA66FD3CE84925B8.description: Identify the type of collateral required for a mortgage loan.

548610A68EDC42DCB01BFC0C1BE98FFA.description: Monthly mortgage payments vary depending on the amount borrowed, the repayment period, and the interest rate, which can be fixed or adjustable.

D21FB64BED2A4D09BA89FE8C421B7BBA.description: Compare what happens if a borrower fails to make required payments on a secured loan, such as an auto loan or a home mortgage, versus failing to pay a credit card account.

3FB164E35F4D4DF3B6F5B711B4BFC4A2.description: Explain why lenders charge lower interest rates on secured loans than on unsecured loans.

9C3D3EC55413423990E6A09269AECB3E.description: Give examples of unsecured and secured loans.

316F82D68CC94F51B81CC8F7AD798EDD.description: Loans that are secured by collateral have lower interest rates than unsecured loans because they are less risky to lenders.

679CC2333B1545C693CCEED92450CE11.description: Compare the cost of borrowing $1,000 using consumer credit options that differ in rates and fees.

3E9751D50D6242E381A25E97379B2D05.description: Describe how credit card grace periods, methods of interest calculation, and fees affect borrowing costs.

535FDD52D6AF4F1689CFC26C5F8F0D29.description: Borrowers can compare the cost of credit using the Annual Percentage Rate (APR) and other terms in the loan or credit card contract.

40DCD2D2CFE14E03852B782601C2CE14.description: Investigate where and how to find qualified financial professionals.

DA7D7F7139534D3A9527D1B1B6E01C73.description: Explain the importance of licensing, certifications, education, and experience as criteria for selecting a financial professional for investment  management or advice.

0ACE02B13A304AF4A058001CA1560E20.description: Discuss reasons that a person might want to hire a financial professional to manage their investments or provide investment advice.

17CF3161393C467B8CE1564704699B88.description: Criteria for selecting financial professionals for investment advice include licensing, certifications, education, experience, and cost.

B2FD8764E7A84A98A8C21F34B1A4EE1D.description: Discuss the advantages of investing in an exchange traded fund (ETF) that tracks a market index rather than investing in actively managed mutual funds or individual stocks and bonds.

76BD37AF04B748C1B33EB0F54F2ECA95.description: Research the composition of the most popular benchmark indices and compare their recent performance.

5CC234C446134E379C7256568645B239.description: Explain why investors often compare portfolio performance to a benchmark such as the S&P 500 Index.

9F29FC1BFDBA4DDA924B8FA5AFE8921B.description: Investors often compare the performance of their investments against a benchmark, such as a diversified stock or bond index.

C4CB3204D6B14F3EB24838678B62D924.description: Explain the importance of having access to full and accurate information about potential investments.

FC8E5096EC3A4C53ADEC50EF400A0CA9.description: Discuss why insider trading is illegal and harmful to investment markets.

31E76F8E40214622800BA9586E1E9270.description: Explain the role of federal regulators in financial markets.

B22058B3CA3B473097FE2068C8132C40.description: Federal regulation of financial markets is designed to ensure that investors have access to accurate information about potential investments and are protected from fraud.

081B7012718A472CBA6515793B3DD720.description: Identify the advantages and disadvantages of roboadvising and other investment-related financial technologies.

757E26F980B2436CB8F4408E312E7E7C.description: Choose a discount broker and research the minimum starting account balance, minimum monthly investment, and trading costs.

12D105BA90004C04A10F55E9CB017D6A.description: Discuss how the development of financial technology has made it easier for people of all income and education levels to participate in financial markets.

F1B45E4149B74A62A1DD60A71C9C8C55.description: Many investors buy and sell financial assets through discount brokerage firms that provide inexpensive investment services and advice using financial technology.

3225D16CA24F4A098F3562154AE6266D.description: Explain how automating investment activities can help people avoid making emotional investment decisions.

00C0C760564E44B89733E3B95EE1962B.description: Explore common financial technologies used for investing, including automated trading platforms.

F247ABDABF7A4F73AF20B2EA280F8112.description: Financial technology can counterbalance negative behavioral factors when making investment decisions.

7D4DF83DB37A4417A383AB9F2BC8E793.description: Brainstorm methods for avoiding negative consequences from behavioral biases.

673F246589F445E28FB28133699505A8.description: Identify several behavioral biases that can result in poor investment decisions (e.g. loss aversion, investing in employer stock, home bias, mental accounting).

6CB36010418A4AC4B06AC22CA253942F.description: Common behavioral biases can result in investors making decisions that adversely affect their investment outcomes.

97C346D6211347209D3C2FD0D8B16994.description: Investigate the contribution limits and tax advantages of a traditional IRA versus a Roth IRA.

0A881C67FC5E4112A9DA75A21A612636.description: Describe the advantages of investing through a tax-deferred account such as an IRA or 401(k) versus a taxable account.

84703DEC921C40E6A692B05370FD58EF.description: Compare tax rates paid on interest income versus short-term and long-term capital gains.

CDF7A03BA0574F768B49A04FFFE15266.description: Tax rules affect the rate of return on different investments, and can vary by holding period, type of income, and type of account.

614A2C211165474AA8F3979F7B0A461B.description: Explain why an actively managed mutual fund usually has a higher expense ratio than an index fund.

EEA29473CCC347538FBA329625AA2455.description: Compare the expense ratios for several mutual funds.

D0A9AA6E30F448BC8ED6123698D614D2.description: Discuss how the expenses associated with buying and selling investments can impact rates of return and investment outcomes.

A16AD717785A4361BDB9AC9FE9A50A45.description: Expenses of buying, selling, and holding financial assets decrease the rate of return from an investment.

0480D027D5204DEBBD5533514E9DCF68.description: Explain how target date retirement funds reallocate investments over time to meet their investment objective.

53D5F66A28004D458F5DC09F64FC4092.description: Suggest an appropriate asset allocation for a very risk averse person versus a very risk tolerant person.

31C140E81A8A48C288A3E56384082DA9.description: Discuss the pros and cons of investing in a diversified mutual fund versus investing in a small number of individual stocks.

C869058FE6DE41C58253D82D20CEF463.description: Recommend portfolio allocation between major asset classes for a short-term goal versus a long-term goal.

71F61397E54540D3A6BE88FF928768E8.description: When making diversification and asset allocation decisions, investors consider their risk tolerance, goals, and investing time horizon.

ACCAE28B08A04057A691EEAEEBA2D54D.description: Explain why the market price of some assets, such as bonds and real estate, increase when interest rates decrease.

884009A42AEA4487BB3CC4976E807372.description: Discuss how economic downturns that result in high unemployment can affect the prices of financial assets.

5031CF6597AC47E9AEBA5D22881560EE.description: Predict what could happen to the price of a stock if new information is reported about the company or its products.

30491A1627CC406CA7B41DDACA1AB1EA.description: Describe factors that influence the prices of financial assets.

A9733E6033CC45B48E1634C2915476B7.description: The prices of financial assets change in response to market conditions, interest rates, company performance, new information, and investor demand.

C4B5572037DB47BCAAF63DDADD7CFF30.description: Find the current rate paid on CDs at a bank and calculate the expected real rate after inflation.

E6F82D3CFE204FA6A0A260C94E8F7779.description: Explain the relationship between nominal and real returns.

BFEE1978A41E4B409DDA1680899ACD05.description: Describe the impact of inflation on prices over time.

A5148AF5ED2E4107928EE1A0B26E65C6.description: Because inflation reduces purchasing power over time, the real return on a financial asset is lower than its nominal return.

55F26857217E40C09D0D44C8D95038F8.description: Explain why bonds with longer maturities generally earn a higher return than shorter-term bonds.

5CD02E3369CA41D2B4B2BADD10ABCF63.description: Explain why the expected rate of return on a value stock or mutual fund is likely to be lower than that of a growth stock or mutual fund.

2227EBD3C0F04100ADED7F85C5B9ECC2.description: Investigate the long-run average rates of returns on small-company stocks, large-company stocks, corporate bonds, and Treasury bonds.

F12A999AEA2E40EAA9A224C1EBAC4D3C.description: Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of investing in riskier assets.

C7C6634D9D314652B3ABB95034D47145.description: Investors expect to earn higher rates of return when they invest in riskier assets.

929C88DA1188405385E647517E169C73.description: Explain why assets that do not produce income or are exposed to large price fluctuation (such as collectibles, precious metals, and cryptocurrencies) are described as speculative investments.

13C4732CA22C4920825CFC2981B587A6.description: Compare nominal annual rates of return over time on different types of investments, including cash flows and price changes.

D5379EBF1B3E440CBEAD47681BFFFBB6.description: Describe the different types of annual cash flows that can be received by investors.

26E08A4B757C42A7B9BD3A73FA6C1E03.description: Investors earn investment returns from price changes and annual cash flows (such as interest, dividends or rent). The nominal annual rate of return is the annual total dollar benefit as a percentage of the beginning price.

B7479680CA6B4006A4E8861F8306018C.description: Assess their personal risk tolerance using an online tool or worksheet.

9007D56BA90D41DFA878E1644A839CB7.description: Discuss how a person’s risk tolerance influences their investment decisions.

327DC7D2D2B8433DB23D29211D814F56.description: Give examples of factors that can influence a person’s risk tolerance.

C769BE2B37B948F4830160F007C5BECD.description: A person’s investment risk tolerance depends on factors such as personality, financial resources, investment experiences, and life circumstances.

0ADF2FA9D92D48E0A216F2575622E47D.description: Explain how the saving strategy “pay yourself first” can help people achieve their saving goals.

1FA9D6D1A67B44739037AEE4CE2FFFB0.description: Discuss strategies for avoiding personal triggers that result in deviating from a savings plan.

5F3368F74B214FC58E86DF61C4CD0DFF.description: Identify strategies to manage psychological and emotional obstacles to saving.

222A8C18CDD144A5B7EBA4769A5AD157.description: Explain how external influences (e.g. peers, family, or social media) can impact personal savings decisions.

F470859CC95E460FA6564F8F789A4B67.description: There are many strategies that can help people manage psychological, emotional, and external obstacles to saving, including automated savings plans, employer matches, and avoiding personal triggers.

A0B8523955514857A0D49524EA2F665B.description: Discuss how personal financial decisions can affect other people.

CDF20C6ED10E4157AF3DA27820C107BD.description: Assess the value of sharing financial goals and personal financial information with a partner before combining finances.

15BB3EC713C04017957086E4863BE996.description: People can reduce the potential for future financial strife with a partner or spouse by sharing personal financial information, goals, and values prior to combining finances.

309FF094D95944BF9B701660C49A0243.description: Explain the benefits of saving money in a health savings account for individuals with high-deductible health plans.

C81253E4ADED4126ADD3A1E33843EF1D.description: Describe the pros and cons of saving through an employer retirement plan as compared to saving outside of an employer plan.

B3BC3D49191E4E63ABD13F0139E2CE6A.description: Compare the impact of employee “opt in” versus “opt out” of employer retirement plans and explain why it makes a difference.

D0BFF2AB9DDB438FB38FBFEC24B10297.description: Explain how an employer match of employee contributions to its retirement plan provides an incentive for employees to save.

B62B73B17E4343ECBEAAC57580208A9D.description: Employer defined contribution retirement plans and health savings accounts can provide incentives for employees to save.

AC4415CB82F44012ACE2BE594BEFAA87.description: Compare the tax advantages of different types of education savings accounts.

D88318278D0E40518FA88BAAA723125A.description: Compare the tax advantages of traditional and Roth IRAs.

118DC0E902084E19959591C63B73A926.description: Explain how traditional IRAs (individual retirement accounts), Roth IRAs, and education savings accounts provide incentives for people to save.

82A216A3E7984898A25EF70C9C29F544.description: Tax policies that allow people to save pretax earnings or to reduce or defer taxes on interest earned provide incentives for people to save.

B50CE265E9014782BDAE2A2D675D36CA.description: Explain the importance of solvency regulation for financial institutions.

A53829E8AA6B4C5582C0D0D7C781021A.description: Identify the state agency responsible for regulating financial institutions where they live.

2A13F14D77CB42D2852744901644AA4A.description: Investigate the areas of financial institution operations that are subject to state and/or federal regulation and supervision.

A43D9F1CE200483F9D7D1AA3C80A0FA0.description: Government agencies such as the Federal Reserve, the FDIC, and the NCUA, along with their counterparts in state government, supervise and regulate financial institutions to improve financial solvency, legal compliance, and consumer protection.

EBB91ACFAFB64A65AF1F88E2EA6F8CB2.description: Investigate how federal I bonds provide inflation protection for savers.

BC76F72192AB4EE9BFF1B05D2E61B54D.description: Illustrate how inflation can reduce the purchasing power of savings over time if the nominal interest rate is lower than the inflation rate.

8A8F863F443041FEBF288BF2B00B5F44.description: Explain why savers typically earn a higher nominal rate of interest when inflation is high.

54099B764950423DACF1C83D3C9198D3.description: Inflation can erode the value of savings if the interest rate earned on a savings account is less than the inflation rate.

B58B82CB804C4C7C86F2BB567C46856A.description: Explain why storing money in a mobile payment account can reduce the ability to grow savings.

3BE5E73B59584C4EB5D2494614137520.description: Compare and contrast the features of mobile payment accounts, cryptocurrency accounts, and checking/savings accounts.

6507E2BBAE5B458CBCEA41B4754D1ACA.description: Unless offered by insured financial institutions, mobile payment accounts and cryptocurrency accounts are not federally insured and usually do not pay interest to depositors.

1B21D4F456BF41B2AA98FCEB2E52F04F.description: Discuss types of market conditions that could result in financial institutions paying lower rates on savings accounts.

4CACEBD3CC114A489BC1EEB411408BE5.description: Explain why an increase in the number of people who want to borrow money might result in banks paying higher rates on deposits.

E2158A793BCC44AEB29B7A3389A285C0.description: Select a preferred location for a savings account based on comparison of interest rates and fees at different types of financial institutions.

F0DF9F8D4E1E4F919930D191CEB2542C.description: Deposit account interest rates and fees vary between financial institutions and depend on market conditions and competition.

802662F7F47546D699D1CAE30B4A6E76.description: Explain why CDs typically pay higher interest rates than regular savings accounts or interest-bearing checking accounts.

D00FE4AC242846B7A28FCAE2243C492C.description: Compare the features of regular savings accounts, money market accounts, and CDs.

01D5B190ECBF4581A740A7A943C16CA1.description: Financial institutions offer several types of savings accounts, including regular savings, money market accounts, and certificates of deposit (CDs), that differ in minimum deposits, rates, and deposit insurance coverage.

DDB468414BE341D48D4825BE87174D29.description: Research financial technology options for financial record-keeping.

E543ECF3404D4D2E83ADD3D78B545682.description: Develop a system for keeping track of spending, saving, and investing.

2A1953E22F364A47B9ADB0316FD90DDA.description: Explain how having a system for financial record-keeping can make it easier to make financial decisions

4F845B99A0554F1285E147F779E559FF.description: Having an organized system for keeping track of spending, saving, and investing makes it easier to make financial decisions.

C476B703CDFE435FB61859A9799BE8C5.description: Make recommendations for sources of help for consumers who have experienced fraud.

8517A28508BB450AB770521A3FDFB6CD.description: Investigate common types of consumer fraud and unfair or deceptive business practices, including online scams, phone solicitations, and redlining.

34F479FA029D4D0799E9C32CC8CF400B.description: Identify state and federal consumer protection laws based on the issues they address and the safeguards they provide.

4FE8009B9DED4C9BB2C91E90F5FFED43.description: Describe the roles and responsibilities of government agencies that help protect consumers from fraud.

E247DFC89EE74BC8A7103365FFAEDD23.description: Federal and state laws, regulations, and consumer protection agencies (e.g., Federal Trade Commission, Consumer Affairs office, and Consumer Financial Protection Bureau) can help individuals avoid unsafe products, unfair practices, and marketplace fraud.

5FCEB546F4D340DD900E90240FA8513F.description: Identify specific steps one should take when researching charitable and other not-for-profit organizations.

00A12CB1D83941A3A3443D5C428B98C4.description: Develop a list of charitable organizations and provide a possible reason that a donor might want to give money to each organization.

7B2E82A0768F40A6965C423B0518C6C3.description: Discuss the motivations for and benefits of donating money, items, or time.

F4A94DA1A4AA4481AF9856D421E7721D.description: People donate money, items, or time to charitable and nonprofit organizations because they value the services provided by the organization and/or gain satisfaction from giving.

6A7CE974A3544C0D82EBFB8D310DE7EF.description: Define key rental contract terminology, including lease term, security deposit, grace period, and eviction.

66A001E534F64CE6B0D39D4D4BA3617D.description: Compare the short-term and long-term costs and benefits of renting versus buying a home in their city of residence.

E2D8BF0231EB414AAC9835850EB8A8E1.description: Identify financial and personal reasons that younger adults often choose to rent a home instead of buying.

B674C5C1C75F4EF99D91514EF702FE0C.description: Housing decisions depend on individual preferences, circumstances, and costs, and can impact personal satisfaction and financial well-being.

01EAEDCA03BF476D84CF82FE5AC329B8.description: Analyze social media marketing and advertising techniques designed to encourage spending.

93E24B0935514559A51ACE3BC2E0DBAC.description: Brainstorm consumer research strategies and resources to use when making purchase decisions.

603D137B17414BB4A06089975F17129E.description: Explain how pre-purchase research encourages consumers to avoid impulse buying.

45FB8533818F457A9BCC23FC505DE0DF.description: Consumers incur costs and realize benefits when searching for information related to the purchase of goods and services.

C325EF7170C04264876016CA025E4C43.description: Summarize how negotiation affects consumer decisions and the price of goods and services.

56D85001441948448743C0DE5F8CB989.description: Describe how inflation affects purchase decisions and the price of goods and services.

7988FC6F97454F4C92172483CFA2493E.description: List different ways retailers advertise the prices of their products.

55E4E66658E741C288D1B685A0A36077.description: Consumers may be influenced by how prices of goods and services are advertised, and whether prices are fixed or negotiable.

B05EDA4518A84C6FBA60C86B18B1121D.description: Compare product choices based on their impacts on the environment or society.

CC0EEA4CB8144D24A61D805A2BDA5179.description: Analyze the cost and features of three competing products or services.

63DA484139D245F283BD58FDB8F51B08.description: Explain the factors to evaluate when buying a durablegood.

069501FDC1A947139CB4C2E97142B03C.description: When purchasing a good that is expected to be used for a long time, consumers consider the product’s durability, maintenance costs, and various product features.

0E8B944D48EB4DD6B3229487D311F9EC.description: List the positive and negative effects of a recent consumer decision on the environment, society, and the economy.

B04E1877F4B04301BD095C7EB2321664.description: Describe a process for making an informed consumer decision.

8C14AE15D3DB45EFA1FA8822FB9541D7.description: Select a product or service and describe the various factors that may influence a consumer’s purchase decision.

52BFBBD059734031B525C0B1093ED73D.description: Consumer decisions are influenced by the price of products or services, the price of alternatives, the consumer’s budget and preferences, and potential impact on the environment, society, and economy.

B1F01B7723684626AB67621431276F86.description: Evaluate the advantages of using budgeting tools, such as spreadsheets or apps.

C9FE86C778F34B2884B061C60CB29B51.description: Explain methods for adjusting a budget for unexpected expenses or emergencies.

95D89B01874345899730C1DB01EDDD47.description: Develop a budget to allocate current income to necessary and desired spending, including estimates for both fixed and variable expenses.

53FAD21170C3492A98E650E6D364144D.description: Identify their short-term and long-term financial goals.

0AB88C0D92DD47BE980666233473DC5B.description: A budget helps people achieve their financial goals by allocating income to necessary and desired spending, saving, and philanthropy.

6AA64DAD3A654102B5740A517FB866CD.description: Discuss the pros and cons of small business ownership as their primary source of income.

95EA226F6F3C4B9894350EC4AB4E9DE0.description: Evaluate the benefits and costs of gig employment, such as driving for a cab or delivery service.

50D0932EDF714BD184068655B79E1F2C.description: Owning a small business can be a person’s primary career or can supplement income from other sources.

5E6F2CAA97734DA1B7C8377C8841F541.description: Report the average benefit paid to a retiree living on Social Security today.

B01E8C41E19E4B0FB37E61C8964BCEEE.description: Explain the importance of participating in employersponsored retirement plans, when available, and contributing enough to qualify for the maximum employer match.

EB5BE6839A2641CBBF91AC9E481DE05B.description: Describe the importance of having multiple sources of income in retirement, such as Social Security, employersponsored retirement plans, and personal investments.

EA5D32FCA4A84D14AD09B95C8C47B857.description: Identify different potential sources of retirement income.

45962C5D0E314512AE96B6A2165666EE.description: Retirement income typically comes from some combination of continued employment earnings, Social Security, employersponsored retirement plans, and personal investments.

E660A35065A241E0A954FBFBC74256DA.description: Identify several examples of tax credits, determining whether they are refundable or non-refundable, and the groups of people who benefit most from each type.

3BDC1E4053BB4D6DB17D0A2307D41583.description: Explain the difference between a tax credit and a tax deduction.

CD99DF12C3294A8E9163E9F3D2E8E6AE.description: Tax deductions and credits reduce income tax liability.

A323A74B8C384574B70D49FE3648C365.description: Compare the tax rates assessed on earned income, interest income, and capital gains income.

A14D8C973CE34F7A8160D014784C7A03.description: Explain the difference between earned and unearned income.

A250C1F79B434FB9A43408AB29AF3E5C.description: Interest, dividends, and capital appreciation (gains) are examples of unearned income derived from financial investments. Capital gains are subject to different tax rates than earned income.

771871EB7D004179BBDBB31940495A45.description: Explain why some income is reported on an IRS Form W-2 and some is reported on an IRS Form 1099, and how that could affect their taxes.

CAC6EFE8993A47708B6675130DEDCC80.description: Differentiate between gross, net, and taxable income.

3AA1A55DC08F45D0A20F9C8566FEA200.description: Compare sales tax rates paid on different types of goods in their state and for online purchases.

F98DBF56440F455B8A6572D4C5963520.description: Investigate the federal and state tax rates applicable to different sources of income.

E94D9AD680EF4EF5B3C2F1BC981BA124.description: The type and amount of taxes people pay depend on their sources of income, amount of income, and amount and type of spending.

B60B3540C585446CA61371FFEA689D81.description: Describe the benefits they receive, or may receive in the future, from government-collected tax revenue.

EC551184A062425FB3574F93DE66283C.description: Identify which level(s) of government typically receive(s) the tax revenue for income taxes, payroll taxes, property taxes, and sales taxes.

F8033E1FB3124EEE9A564716EBD350E4.description: Calculate the amount of taxes a person is likely to pay when given information or data about the person’s sources of income and amount of spending.

90CE014006E74383B35A1E95CB271467.description: Federal, state, and local taxes fund government-provided goods, services, and transfer payments to individuals. The major types of taxes are income taxes, payroll taxes, property taxes, and sales taxes.

7143220C49C6446799CF86A2E6ED68FC.description: Discuss the effects of an economic downturn on employment opportunities for people with different characteristics, such as education, experience, employment type, ethnicity, and gender.

B4E3AA2F2753415BAEC1AC27AA9764F5.description: Evaluate the impact of technological advances on employment and income.

7E3867DE93B04F7EAE7EB8E7CF7DD4B9.description: Discuss how economic and labor market conditions can affect income, career opportunities, and employment status.

115BAEEF9E424D359EEE45C89C35553F.description: Changes in economic conditions, technology, or the labor market can cause changes in income, career opportunities, or employment status.

8FE04753E705445F972F672C60C0FC92.description: Discuss possible explanations for the persistence of race and gender pay gaps.

5A10B6892F5D44E1B7E019E3024341CD.description: Explain why wages or salaries vary among employees in different types of jobs and among workers in the same jobs.

937000B22A344CFBB50B10C287AB9FD0.description: Identify different types of jobs and careers where wages and salaries depend on a worker’s productivity and skills.

9F6386461E38484294665010740477CD.description: Employers generally pay higher wages or salaries to more educated, skilled, and productive workers than to less educated, skilled, and productive workers.

B7890851D7A7429895DC9014EB3127FF.description: Compare earnings and unemployment rates by level of education and training.

C23AF9AB28E34CD4A4E83B024BE4290A.description: Explain how differences in people’s life circumstances can affect their opportunity and willingness to further their education or training.

FD8F536972C74225B25EEFAD18FA7ECA.description: Evaluate the costs and benefits of investing in additional education or training.

90983F4015684C3394DE724CC1F86C48.description: People vary in their opportunity and willingness to incur the present costs of additional training and education in exchange for future benefits, such as earning potential.

58AA58EFE40D45AF965D843D003B69AD.description: Evaluate the tradeoffs between income and non-income factors when making career or job choices.

C32A2C817EA24667BFD9499C2C9889F6.description: Describe how intangible benefits can affect a worker’s career choices and income.

3B66324F4A5D49A3BE53C1B3077BB282.description: Give examples of intangible job benefits

090F3E599D3140A295BB60F09DC81F2C.description: In addition to wages and paid benefits, employees may also value intangible (noncash) benefits, such as good working conditions, flexible work hours, telecommuting privileges, and career advancement potential.

3C890F1F1BBB4D5DA7EEAE26D736A3CD.description: Examine the benefits of participating in employersponsored retirement savings plans and healthcare savings plans.

11A3B1A2A023449CB4548343E1CF8D42.description: Differentiate between contributory and non-contributory employee benefits.

A0E52F34B5EE44D496BBFCF56EF45508.description: Explain why people should evaluate employee benefits in addition to wages and salaries when choosing between job and career opportunities.

F70F99D2B53843DFAC278D2502780C13.description: Research potential income and employee benefit packages that are likely to be offered to new employees by various companies, government agencies, or not-forprofit organizations.

9012560D9A1A4934A40F191807C09081.description: Compensation for a job or career can be in the form of wages, salaries, commissions, tips, or bonuses, and may also include contributions to employee benefits, such as health insurance, retirement savings plans, and education reimbursement programs.
